unnormalised: Okay, so you know how things are changing fast in the business world, right? It feels like every other week there’s a new designation popping up. Let’s talk about some of the titles you might encounter, especially in Indian companies. I mean, from “Chief Everything Officer” (okay, maybe not that one, but close!) to the more traditional ones, it's good to have a handle on who's who.
normalised: Okay, so you know how things are changing fast in the business world, right? It feels like every other week there's a new designation popping up. Let's talk about some of the titles you might encounter, especially in Indian companies. I mean, from "Chief Everything Officer" (okay, maybe not that one, but close!) to the more traditional ones, it's good to have a handle on who's who.

unnormalised: Firstly, the classics. You can't go wrong knowing your CEOs, CFOs, and COOs. The CEO, or Chief Executive Officer, is still very much the top dog. Think of someone like Mr. Mukesh Ambani or Ms. Roshni Nadar Malhotra. They're steering the ship. Then you have the CFO, the Chief Financial Officer. They’re keeping track of all the paise and ensuring the company isn't going to go belly up any time soon. Someone like Mr. Saurabh Agarwal at Tata Sons. The COO, Chief Operating Officer, is the person making sure the trains run on time, ya know? Handling the day-to-day operations.
normalised: Firstly, the classics. You can't go wrong knowing your C-E-Os, C-F-Os, and C-O-Os. The C-E-O, or Chief Executive Officer, is still very much the top dog. Think of someone like Mister Mukesh Ambani or Miss Roshni Nadar Malhotra. They're steering the ship. Then you have the C-F-O, the Chief Financial Officer. They're keeping track of all the paise and ensuring the company isn't going to go belly up any time soon. Someone like Mister Saurabh Agarwal at Tata Sons. The C-O-O, Chief Operating Officer, is the person making sure the trains run on time, ya know? Handling the day-to-day operations.

unnormalised: Now, let's get a little more modern. You might see a “Head of Growth” a lot these days. That's someone focused on, well, growth! Pretty self-explanatory. They might be in charge of marketing, sales, and partnerships – basically, anything that brings in more customers and revenue. Or a "Chief Marketing Officer (CMO) leading teams. Remember meeting Ms. Priya Sharma, CMO, at the conference?

unnormalised: Then there are the tech titles that didn't even exist a few years ago. Think "Chief Technology Officer" (CTO) driving technical vision or a "Chief Data Officer" (CDO) ensuring data-driven decisions. These folks are super important, especially with all the AI and machine learning stuff happening now. You’ll often find a "VP of Engineering" leading development teams.
normalised: Then there are the tech titles that didn't even exist a few years ago. Think "Chief Technology Officer" (C-T-O) driving technical vision or a "Chief Data Officer" (C-D-O) ensuring data-driven decisions. These folks are super important, especially with all the A-I and machine learning stuff happening now. You'll often find a "V-P of Engineering" leading development teams.

unnormalised: What about the ones that sound important but you're not quite sure what they do? Like "Chief Strategy Officer" (CSO)? They are involved in long-term planning and direction. "Head of HR" is usually pretty straightforward, looking after the employees and making sure everyone’s happy (or at least, not too unhappy!).
normalised: What about the ones that sound important but you're not quite sure what they do? Like "Chief Strategy Officer" (C-S-O)? They are involved in long-term planning and direction. "Head of H-R" is usually pretty straightforward, looking after the employees and making sure everyone's happy (or at least, not too unhappy!).

unnormalised: And don't forget the regional variations. In many Indian companies, you might still find the "Director" title used a lot, often equivalent to a VP in a Western context. You might hear of "Managing Director" (MD) who is running operations on the ground in India, but maybe is not the global CEO.
normalised: And don't forget the regional variations. In many Indian companies, you might still find the "Director" title used a lot, often equivalent to a V-P in a Western context. You might hear of "Managing Director" (M-D) who is running operations on the ground in India, but maybe is not the global C-E-O.

unnormalised: Navigating these titles is important for networking, understanding the company's structure, and just generally knowing who to talk to when you need something. So, the next time you get a business card with a fancy title, you'll at least have a fighting chance of understanding what that person actually does! And remember, it's always okay to ask for clarification. No one expects you to know everything, bhai!
